problem_text:
We say that a finite group G separates cyclic subgroups if, for any cyclic subgroups A and B of G, there is a g ∈ G such that A ∩ B^g = 1. Is it true that G separates cyclic subgroups if and only if G has no non-trivial cyclic normal subgroups?
J. G. Thompson
answer: Not always. For p1 = 2, p2 = 5, p3 = 11, p4 = 17 let Ri be an elementary abelian group of order p_i^2 and φi a regular automorphism of order 3 of Ri, i = 1, 2, 3, 4. In the direct product R1⟨φ1⟩ × R2⟨φ2⟩ × R3⟨φ3⟩ × R4⟨φ4⟩ let G be the subgroup generated by all the Ri and the elements φ2φ3φ4 and φ1φ3φ−1 4. Then G has no non-trivial cyclic normal subgroups and every (cyclic) subgroup of order 2 · 5 · 11 · 17 intersects any of its conjugates non-trivially. (N. D. Podufalov, Abstracts of the 9th All-Union Group Theory Symp., Moscow, 1984, 113–114 (Russian).)
